content.webTitle: Sunrise segment on Indigenous adoption lands Seven in more hot water

fields.headline: Sunrise segment on Indigenous adoption lands Seven in more hot water
fields.bodyText: The communications watchdog has ramped up the penalty against Sunrise for provoking serious contempt on the basis of race by airing an all-white panel discussion of Indigenous children and child abuse. The breakfast program has agreed to a court-enforcable undertaking to conduct an independent review of the program’s production processes and retrain staff in dealing with sensitive and complex issues. Last year the Australian Communications and Media Authority found that Sunrise breached broadcasting standards for accuracy and provoked serious contempt on the basis of race when co-host Samantha Armytage and guests discussed the adoption of Indigenous children. Commentators Prue MacSween and Ben Davis made strong negative generalisations about Indigenous people as a group. The panel did not include any Indigenous person, made several factually wrong statements, and aired comments by MacSween that the stolen generations policy removed children for their own wellbeing and “perhaps” should happen again. “These included sweeping references to a ‘generation’ of young Indigenous children being abused,” Acma said last year. “While it may not have been Seven’s intention, by implication the segment conveyed that children left in Indigenous families would be abused and neglected, in contrast to non-Indigenous families where they would be protected.” Seven challenged the finding but in April it withdrew the application for judicial review. Acma said on Friday Sunrise has to order an external independent review of how the program is produced and a report of the review must be provided to Seven’s board within six months. The media watchdog will verify the independence of, and terms of reference for, the review. The network has also agreed to train Sunrise editorial staff to identify and deal with sensitive matters, also within six months. Sunrise breached the Commercial TV Code of Practice in its Hot Topics segment broadcast in March 2018. “If Channel Seven breaches the court-enforceable undertaking, the Acma can apply to the federal court for a number of orders, including directing Channel Seven to comply with the undertaking, and any other order the court considers appropriate,” Acma said. Seven’s director of news and public affairs, Craig McPherson, blamed political correctness and censorship for the Acma decision last year.
